text:
## Description
Jollof rice is a West African rice dish cooked in a tomato-based sauce with onions, peppers, and spices. Often served with chicken, beef, or fish.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup cooked)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.3 g | Fat: 8.5 g | Carbohydrates: 32.1 g | Iron: 1.2 mg | Calcium: 25 mg | Vitamin A: 450 µg | Zinc: 0.8 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Palm oil or vegetable oil adds fat; tomato paste boosts vitamin A; protein varies with meat/fish additions.

## Local context
Popular at celebrations and parties across Nigeria. Regional variations exist (Lagos vs. Northern styles).

## Description
Pounded yam is a starchy side dish made from boiled yam that is pounded until smooth and stretchy. It is often served with various soups and stews.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 2.0 g | Fat: 0.3 g | Carbohydrates: 38.0 g | Iron: 0.6 mg | Calcium: 20 mg | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 0.4 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Yam can be boiled and pounded with a mortar and pestle or a stand mixer. The texture can vary based on the amount of water used.

## Local context
A staple food in Nigeria, commonly paired with soups like egusi or ogbono. It is a traditional dish at ceremonies and gatherings.

## Description
Fufu is a starchy side dish made from boiled and pounded starchy vegetables like yam, cassava, or plantains, forming a smooth, stretchy dough-like consistency. This entry represents cassava-based fufu.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 1.0 g | Fat: 0.5 g | Carbohydrates: 62.0 g | Iron: 0.5 mg | Calcium: 15 mg | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 0.3 mg

## Preparation adjustments
The choice of base (yam, cassava, or plantain) affects the nutrient profile; typically served with soups and stews. Cassava contains trace minerals. Plantain fufu has 55-60g carbs, cocoyam fufu has 65-70g carbs.

## Local context
A staple in Nigerian cuisine, fufu is often eaten with soups like egusi or ogbono and is popular across various regions.

## Description
Suya is a popular Nigerian street food consisting of skewered and grilled spicy meat, typically beef or chicken, seasoned with a blend of spices and served with sliced onions and tomatoes.

## Typical portion
100 g (2-3 skewers)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 25.0 g | Fat: 15.0 g | Carbohydrates: 5.0 g | Iron: 2.0 mg | Calcium: 10 mg | Vitamin A: 0 µg | Zinc: 4.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Marination with groundnut (peanut) powder enhances flavor; spices can vary regionally; serving with vegetables increases nutrient diversity.

## Local context
Widely enjoyed as a street food snack or at social gatherings, suya is a staple in northern Nigeria and has gained popularity nationwide.

## Description
Moi Moi is a traditional Nigerian steamed bean pudding made from blended black-eyed peas, peppers, onions, and spices. It can include fish or eggs for added flavor.

## Typical portion
150 g (1 serving)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 12.0 g | Fat: 5.0 g | Carbohydrates: 15.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 30 mg | Vitamin A: 200 µg | Zinc: 0.6 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Adding fish or eggs increases protein; using palm oil enhances flavor and vitamin A content. Black-eyed peas are protein-rich (21-24g per 100g dry weight).

## Local context
Often served at parties, weddings, and as a side dish with rice. Popular across Nigeria with regional variations.

## Description
Pepper soup is a spicy, broth-based soup popular in Nigeria, made with various meats (goat, chicken, fish) and flavored with a blend of spices and pepper.

## Typical portion
300 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.0 g | Fat: 5.0 g | Carbohydrates: 2.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 25 mg | Vitamin A: 50 µg | Zinc: 0.9 mg

## Preparation adjustments
The spice mix can vary; adding more meat increases protein; fish versions may enhance omega-3 content. Bones and cartilage contribute calcium.

## Local context
Often served at social gatherings and as a remedy for colds. Variants exist across different ethnic groups in Nigeria.

## Description
Akara is a popular Nigerian snack made from blended black-eyed peas, onions, and spices, deep-fried until golden brown.

## Typical portion
100 g (about 4-5 pieces)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 9.0 g | Fat: 15.0 g | Carbohydrates: 30.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 50 mg | Vitamin A: 50 µg | Zinc: 0.6 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Can be made with different spices or vegetables; frying method affects fat content. Deep-frying absorbs oil nutrients including vitamin A.

## Local context
Commonly served as a breakfast item or snack, often enjoyed with pap (fermented corn pudding) or custard.

## Description
Efo Riro is a traditional Nigerian vegetable soup made with a variety of leafy greens, tomatoes, peppers, and often includes meats or fish for added flavor.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.0 g | Fat: 10.0 g | Carbohydrates: 5.0 g | Iron: 3.0 mg | Calcium: 80 mg | Vitamin A: 350 µg | Zinc: 1.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Palm oil enhances flavor and adds fat (rich in vitamin A and E); leafy greens like spinach are packed with iron and calcium; meat or fish increases protein.

## Local context
Popular in Yoruba cuisine, often served with rice or fufu. Variations exist based on local ingredients and preferences.

## Description
Ewa Agoyin is a Nigerian dish made from mashed black-eyed peas served with a spicy pepper sauce. It is popular in Lagos and often enjoyed with bread or rice.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 plate)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 14.0 g | Fat: 5.0 g | Carbohydrates: 32.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 40 mg | Vitamin A: 150 µg | Zinc: 0.6 mg

## Preparation adjustments
The sauce can be adjusted for spiciness; palm oil in the pepper sauce adds fat and vitamin A content.

## Local context
Commonly eaten as a street food or breakfast item, especially in the southwestern regions of Nigeria.

## Description
Okra soup is a popular Nigerian dish made from fresh okra, often combined with meat, fish, and spices, resulting in a thick, viscous texture.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.0 g | Fat: 7.0 g | Carbohydrates: 8.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 81 mg | Vitamin A: 700 µg | Zinc: 0.6 mg

## Preparation adjustments
The addition of palm oil increases fat and vitamin A; meat or fish enhances protein content; can be thickened with ground seeds. Raw okra provides fiber and magnesium.

## Local context
Often served with fufu, pounded yam, or rice. A staple in many Nigerian households, especially in the southern regions.

## Description
Ogbono soup is a Nigerian soup made from ground ogbono seeds (wild mango), which gives it a unique slimy texture. It is often cooked with assorted meats, fish, and leafy vegetables.

## Typical portion
250 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 7.0 g | Fat: 10.0 g | Carbohydrates: 5.0 g | Iron: 2.5 mg | Calcium: 50 mg | Vitamin A: 350 µg | Zinc: 1.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Palm oil adds fat and vitamin A; meat/fish increases protein; vegetables can enhance iron and calcium content.

## Local context
Popular in various Nigerian regions, often served with fufu or pounded yam. Known for its unique texture and flavor.

## Description
Rice and stew is a staple Nigerian dish consisting of boiled rice served with a rich tomato-based stew, often containing meat or fish.

## Typical portion
250 g (1 plate)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.0 g | Fat: 10.0 g | Carbohydrates: 35.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 30 mg | Vitamin A: 300 µg | Zinc: 0.7 mg

## Preparation adjustments
The stew can vary in fat content based on the type of oil used; additional vegetables can enhance nutrient density.

## Local context
A common dish in Nigerian households, often served at family gatherings and celebrations.

## Description
Beans and stew is a popular Nigerian dish made from cooked beans served with a rich tomato-based stew, often including onions, peppers, and spices. It can be served with rice or bread.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup cooked beans with stew)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 14.0 g | Fat: 5.0 g | Carbohydrates: 32.0 g | Iron: 2.5 mg | Calcium: 30 mg | Vitamin A: 200 µg | Zinc: 1.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
The stew can vary in fat content depending on the amount of oil used; adding meat or fish increases protein and zinc.

## Local context
A staple in many Nigerian households, often enjoyed with rice, plantains, or bread, especially during festive occasions.

## Description
Eba is a Nigerian staple food made from garri, which is processed cassava. It is typically served as an accompaniment to soups and stews.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 1.5 g | Fat: 0.3 g | Carbohydrates: 62.0 g | Iron: 0.4 mg | Calcium: 10 mg | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 0.3 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Eba is made by mixing garri with hot water until it forms a smooth dough. The texture can be adjusted by varying the water content.

## Local context
Eba is widely consumed across Nigeria and is often paired with soups like egusi or ogbono. It is a key part of many Nigerian meals.

## Description
Fried plantain, known as dodo in Nigeria, is a popular dish made from ripe plantains sliced and fried until golden brown. It is often served as a side dish or snack.

## Typical portion
150 g (about 3-4 slices)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 1.3 g | Fat: 9.0 g | Carbohydrates: 37.0 g | Iron: 0.6 mg | Calcium: 5 mg | Vitamin A: 200 µg | Zinc: 0.2 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Frying in oil increases fat content; can be seasoned with spices or served with sauces for added flavor.

## Local context
Commonly enjoyed with rice dishes, stews, or as a standalone snack. Popular at parties and gatherings.

## Description
Chicken stew is a flavorful Nigerian dish made with chicken, tomatoes, onions, and spices. It is often served with rice or yam.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 20.0 g | Fat: 15.0 g | Carbohydrates: 5.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 30 mg | Vitamin A: 500 µg | Zinc: 2.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Oil used in cooking can vary; adding vegetables can enhance nutrient content; spices can be adjusted for flavor.

## Local context
A staple in Nigerian households, often served during special occasions and family gatherings.

## Description
Fish stew is a flavorful Nigerian dish made with fish, tomatoes, onions, and spices, often served with rice or yam.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 15.0 g | Fat: 10.0 g | Carbohydrates: 5.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 50 mg | Vitamin A: 300 µg | Zinc: 1.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Oil type and quantity can alter fat content; spices can enhance flavor without adding calories; fish type affects protein and omega-3 content.

## Local context
A staple in many Nigerian households, often prepared for special occasions and served with rice or plantains.

## Description
Bread and eggs is a simple and popular breakfast dish in Nigeria, typically consisting of fried or scrambled eggs served with slices of bread.

## Typical portion
2 slices of bread (100 g) with 2 eggs (100 g)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 12.0 g | Fat: 10.0 g | Carbohydrates: 30.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 50 mg | Vitamin A: 300 µg | Zinc: 1.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Eggs can be cooked in various styles (fried, scrambled); bread can be white or whole grain, affecting nutrient content.

## Local context
Commonly enjoyed as a quick breakfast or snack, often accompanied by tea or coffee.

## Description
Pap, also known as Ogi or Akamu, is a fermented cereal pudding made from maize, sorghum, or millet. It is a staple breakfast food in Nigeria, often served with sugar or milk.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 2.0 g | Fat: 0.5 g | Carbohydrates: 22.0 g | Iron: 0.4 mg | Calcium: 5 mg | Vitamin A: 30 µg | Zinc: 0.4 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Fermentation enhances digestibility; can be thickened or diluted with water or milk; sweeteners can be added. Micronutrient content is very low unless fortified.

## Local context
Commonly consumed by infants and adults alike, often paired with Akara (bean cakes) or eaten alone.

## Description
Ofada rice is a locally grown Nigerian rice variety, often served with Ayamase, a spicy green pepper sauce made with green bell peppers, onions, and assorted meats.

## Typical portion
300 g (1.5 cups cooked rice with sauce)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 7.0 g | Fat: 10.0 g | Carbohydrates: 35.0 g | Iron: 1.5 mg | Calcium: 20 mg | Vitamin A: 300 µg | Zinc: 1.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Ayamase sauce can vary in spice level; adding more meat increases protein and fat content.

## Local context
A staple in southwestern Nigeria, often enjoyed at special occasions and gatherings.

## Description
Oha soup is a traditional Igbo soup made from oha leaves, thickened with cocoyam and often cooked with assorted meats and spices. It is known for its rich flavor and nutritional benefits.

## Typical portion
250 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 8.0 g | Fat: 10.0 g | Carbohydrates: 6.0 g | Iron: 3.0 mg | Calcium: 50 mg | Vitamin A: 350 µg | Zinc: 1.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Cocoyam serves as a thickener; palm oil adds fat and vitamin A; meat choices can vary protein content.

## Local context
Commonly enjoyed in Eastern Nigeria, especially during festive occasions and family gatherings.

## Description
Afang soup is a nutritious Nigerian soup made from afang leaves (okazi), waterleaf, palm oil, and assorted meats or fish. It is known for its rich flavor and health benefits, being high in vitamins and minerals.

## Typical portion
250 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 9.0 g | Fat: 14.0 g | Carbohydrates: 5.0 g | Iron: 3.5 mg | Calcium: 95 mg | Vitamin A: 400 µg | Zinc: 1.8 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Palm oil increases vitamin A and fat content; the combination of afang and waterleaf enhances iron and calcium levels; the addition of fish or meat boosts protein and zinc.

## Local context
Afang soup is a staple in southeastern Nigeria, particularly in Cross River and Akwa Ibom states, and is often served with fufu or pounded yam.

## Description
Edikang Ikong is a rich Nigerian vegetable soup made primarily from fluted pumpkin leaves (ugu) and waterleaf, often cooked with assorted meats and fish. Known for its nutritional value and vibrant flavor.

## Typical portion
250 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 14.2 g | Fat: 12.0 g | Carbohydrates: 6.0 g | Iron: 2.5 mg | Calcium: 90 mg | Vitamin A: 750 µg | Zinc: 1.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Palm oil enhances flavor and vitamin A; the variety of meats/fish adds protein and zinc; can be adjusted for thickness by varying the amount of waterleaf.

## Local context
A traditional dish in southeastern Nigeria, especially popular in Cross River and Akwa Ibom states, often served with fufu or pounded yam.

## Description
Banga soup is a rich Nigerian soup made from palm nut extract, spices, and various meats or fish. It is known for its unique flavor and thick consistency.

## Typical portion
250 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 8.0 g | Fat: 20.0 g | Carbohydrates: 6.0 g | Iron: 2.5 mg | Calcium: 30 mg | Vitamin A: 500 µg | Zinc: 1.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Palm nut extract contributes to fat and vitamin A; spices enhance flavor; meat/fish add protein and minerals.

## Local context
Commonly enjoyed in the Niger Delta region, often served with starches like pounded yam or fufu.

## Description
Nkwobi is a traditional Igbo dish made from cow foot cooked in a spicy palm oil sauce, often garnished with utazi leaves. It is typically served in a small bowl.

## Typical portion
150 g (1 serving)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 16.0 g | Fat: 20.0 g | Carbohydrates: 5.0 g | Iron: 2.5 mg | Calcium: null | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 3.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
The richness of the dish can be adjusted by varying the amount of palm oil and spices used. Additional ingredients like potash may enhance flavor.

## Local context
Nkwobi is popular in bars and restaurants in Eastern Nigeria, often enjoyed as a delicacy with drinks.

## Description
Abacha, also known as African salad, is a traditional dish made from fermented and dried African star apple (or cassava) served with palm oil, onions, and various toppings like fish or meat.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 plate)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.0 g | Fat: 15.0 g | Carbohydrates: 45.0 g | Iron: 2.5 mg | Calcium: 50 mg | Vitamin A: 200 µg | Zinc: 1.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Palm oil adds fat and vitamin A; toppings like fish increase protein and zinc; can be served with vegetables for added nutrients.

## Local context
Commonly enjoyed in Eastern Nigeria, especially among the Ibo people, often served at social gatherings and celebrations.

aliases: yam and goat meat pepper soup

text:
## Description
Ukodo, or yam pepper soup, is a traditional Nigerian dish made with yam, assorted meats (often goat), and a spicy pepper soup broth. It is known for its warming and comforting qualities.

## Typical portion
300 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.0 g | Fat: 3.0 g | Carbohydrates: 20.0 g | Iron: 0.9 mg | Calcium: 15 mg | Vitamin A: 0 µg | Zinc: 0.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
The spiciness can be adjusted with different types of peppers; the choice of meat affects protein and fat content.

## Local context
Commonly enjoyed in various Nigerian regions, especially during the rainy season or as a remedy for colds.

## Description
Boli & Groundnut is a popular Nigerian street food consisting of grilled plantains served with groundnut (peanut) sauce. It is a flavorful and nutritious snack.

## Typical portion
200 g (2 medium plantains with groundnut)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.0 g | Fat: 15.0 g | Carbohydrates: 30.0 g | Iron: 0.8 mg | Calcium: 40 mg | Vitamin A: 0 µg | Zinc: 1.0 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Grilling enhances flavor; groundnut adds protein and fat; portion size can vary based on personal preference.

## Local context
Commonly sold by street vendors in Nigeria, especially in urban areas. Often enjoyed as a snack or light meal.

## Description
Masa is a traditional Nigerian rice cake made from fermented rice batter, often flavored with spices and sometimes served with a spicy sauce or yogurt.

## Typical portion
100 g (about 3-4 cakes)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 3.0 g | Fat: 1.5 g | Carbohydrates: 30.0 g | Iron: 0.5 mg | Calcium: 10 mg | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 0.4 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Fermentation enhances flavor; can be fried or baked; served with various dips or sauces.

## Local context
Commonly enjoyed in Northern Nigeria, often as a breakfast item or snack, and popular at social gatherings.

## Description
Plain white rice is a staple food in Nigeria, often served as a side dish with various soups and stews. It is typically boiled or steamed until tender.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup cooked)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 2.7 g | Fat: 0.3 g | Carbohydrates: 28.6 g | Iron: 0.2 mg | Calcium: 3 mg | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 0.4 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Cooking time and water ratio can affect texture; can be flavored with spices or served with sauces.

## Local context
Commonly served with jollof rice, fried rice, or various Nigerian soups. A versatile accompaniment in many meals.

## Description
Nigerian-style spaghetti is a popular dish made with spaghetti noodles cooked in a rich tomato sauce, often with vegetables and proteins like chicken or beef.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 plate cooked)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 5.0 g | Fat: 7.0 g | Carbohydrates: 30.0 g | Iron: 0.6 mg | Calcium: 10 mg | Vitamin A: 150 µg | Zinc: 0.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Adding vegetables like bell peppers and carrots increases vitamins; meat options vary protein content.

## Local context
Commonly served in homes and at gatherings, often enjoyed with a side of fried plantains.

## Description
Indomie noodles are a popular brand of instant noodles in Nigeria, known for their quick preparation and variety of flavors. Often enjoyed with vegetables, eggs, or meat.

## Typical portion
85 g (1 pack)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 8.0 g | Fat: 14.0 g | Carbohydrates: 60.0 g | Iron: 1.0 mg | Calcium: 10 mg | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 0.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Can be enhanced with vegetables, eggs, or proteins to increase nutritional value.

## Local context
A staple in many Nigerian households, especially among students and young adults, often consumed as a quick meal or snack.

## Description
Nigerian fried rice is a colorful dish made with parboiled rice, mixed vegetables, and spices, often served at parties and celebrations. It is typically cooked with oil and may include proteins like chicken or shrimp.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup cooked)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 5.0 g | Fat: 10.0 g | Carbohydrates: 30.0 g | Iron: 1.0 mg | Calcium: 20 mg | Vitamin A: 300 µg | Zinc: 0.7 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Vegetables like carrots and peas add vitamins; oil increases fat content; protein varies with meat or seafood additions.

## Local context
A staple at Nigerian parties and gatherings, often served alongside jollof rice and other dishes.

## Description
Yam porridge, known as Asaro, is a traditional Nigerian dish made from yam, palm oil, and spices. It is creamy and often enjoyed as a comfort food.

## Typical portion
300 g (1 bowl)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 2.0 g | Fat: 5.0 g | Carbohydrates: 27.0 g | Iron: 0.6 mg | Calcium: 20 mg | Vitamin A: 150 µg | Zinc: 0.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Palm oil adds fat and vitamin A; spices can vary for flavor; additional vegetables can enhance nutrient content.

## Local context
Commonly prepared in many Nigerian households, especially in the southwestern region. Often served with fish or meat.

## Description
Beans porridge is a traditional Nigerian dish made from cooked beans, often flavored with palm oil, spices, and sometimes vegetables. It is hearty and nutritious.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 7.0 g | Fat: 2.5 g | Carbohydrates: 27.0 g | Iron: 2.5 mg | Calcium: 30 mg | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 0.6 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Palm oil can be added for flavor and fat; spices vary by region; vegetables can enhance nutrient content.

## Local context
Commonly eaten across Nigeria, especially in the southwest. Often served with rice or yam.

## Description
Boiled yam and egg sauce is a popular Nigerian dish consisting of boiled yam served with a sauce made from eggs, tomatoes, onions, and spices. It is a hearty and nutritious meal.

## Typical portion
300 g (1 medium yam tuber with sauce)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.5 g | Fat: 10.0 g | Carbohydrates: 30.0 g | Iron: 0.9 mg | Calcium: 50 mg | Vitamin A: 200 µg | Zinc: 0.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Cooking yam with minimal water retains nutrients; adding vegetables to egg sauce can enhance vitamins and minerals.

## Local context
Commonly enjoyed for breakfast or lunch across Nigeria, often accompanied by pepper sauce or vegetables.

## Description
Oats porridge is a warm breakfast dish made from rolled or instant oats cooked in water or milk. It can be sweetened with sugar or honey and flavored with fruits or nuts.

## Typical portion
200 g (1 cup cooked)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 2.5 g | Fat: 1.5 g | Carbohydrates: 12.0 g | Iron: 0.6 mg | Calcium: 18 mg | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 0.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Can be made with water or milk; adding fruits or nuts increases nutritional value; sweeteners can vary.

## Local context
Commonly consumed for breakfast across Nigeria, often paired with fruits or honey for added flavor.

## Description
Tea and bread is a common breakfast or snack in Nigeria, consisting of brewed tea served with various types of bread, often accompanied by butter or margarine.

## Typical portion
1 cup of tea (200 ml) and 2 slices of bread (100 g)

## Nutrient highlights
Protein: 6.0 g | Fat: 8.0 g | Carbohydrates: 45.0 g | Iron: 1.0 mg | Calcium: 50 mg | Vitamin A: null | Zinc: 0.5 mg

## Preparation adjustments
Tea can be made with milk or sugar; bread type (white, whole wheat) affects nutrient content.

## Local context
Widely consumed across Nigeria, often enjoyed in homes, cafes, and roadside eateries.
